answers.answer: Hi,It is possible that although in the past your fasting sugars were normal, your post-glucose numbers were high enough to do some damage.  Also, cnosider that some of your complications may not all be due to diabetes, so discuss that more with your doctor.The glucose numbers you gave are very good, so I do not think you need an Endocrinologist for glucose control. But you may consider checking your blood sugars a few other times during the day and definitely if you wake up in a sweat. It would be very unusual to have glucose numbers low enough to cause sweats when you are not on medication, unless something else has gone awry. You shoud be evaluated(possibly first by your primary doctor) for the cause of those night sweats.Hope this helps,take care.

question: I am a 51 year old male diagnosed with T2 in late June through an OGTT.   Both the one hour and two hour ranges were over 200.  Diabetes was first suspected about 10 years ago but my fasting blood numbers and A1C were always borderline.  Since the T2 diagnose I have also been diagnosed with a number of complications including the beginning of a cataract and neuropathy in my feet.  I have also suffered from various temporary neuralgias over the years. Mainly the neuralgias imitated shingles but there was never any blistering.   Emergency gall bladder surgery two years ago may also have been a complication since I suffered no pain until peritonitis developed.  I don’t understand why I am experiencing so many complications if my blood sugar was never all that high.  I am overweight but never obese I am treating my diabetes only through diet and exercise.  I’ve dropped 20 pounds and am only 7 pounds above the normal range for my height (5’3”).  My last A1C was in the normal range.  I test twice a day once in morning and once before dinner.  My morning count is usually somewhere around 110 and my evening range is between 75 and 90.  Night sweats were also an issue.  Is it possible I was having hypoglycemic reactions even if I’m not on medication?  Should I see an endocrinologist and if so what tests should I request?  Thank you for your time.
title: Complications at Low Sugar Levels?
